item.title: Saudi King Seeks Warmer Ties With Russia, a Historic Foe
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with King Salman of Saudi Arabia at the Kremlin on Thursday.
item.description: King Salman’s trip, the first state visit by a Saudi monarch, is a sign of the shifting dynamics in the Middle East as Russia assumes a greater role.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Spanish Court Moves to Pre-empt Catalan Independence Declaration
item.media:description: A session of Catalonia’s regional Parliament in September. A Spanish court on Thursday suspended the body’s session that was to be held on Monday.
item.description: The country’s constitutional court blocked a session of the regional Parliament scheduled to take place on Monday.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Iraq Claims Victory in ISIS’ Last Urban Stronghold
item.media:description: Iraqi forces and Shiite militias advancing toward the former Islamic State stronghold of Hawija on Thursday.
item.description: With the fall of Hawija, the militants’ foothold has been reduced to a shrinking area along the Euphrates River in Iraq and substantial territory across the border in Syria.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Minsk Journal: How Europe’s Last Dictatorship Became a Tech Hub
item.media:description: The company Wargaming employs some of the more than 30,000 tech specialists now working in Minsk, Belarus.
item.media:credit: Siarhei Hudzilin for The New York Times
item.description: Minsk, the capital of Belarus, is home to more than 30,000 tech workers, and many of them are creating mobile apps used across the world.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Young Worker Clocked 159 Hours of Overtime in a Month. Then She Died.
item.media:description: The newsroom of the Japanese broadcaster NHK in 2012. Inspectors determined that the grueling work schedule of a young journalist who worked there led to her death in 2013.
item.media:credit: Kosuke Okhara for The New York Times
item.description: Miwa Sado, 31, a journalist for Japan’s state-run broadcaster, is the latest high-profile example of karoshi, or “death from overwork.”
item.dc:creator: MAKIKO INOUE and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: U.S. Halt in Visa Services Leaves Cuban Families in Limbo
item.media:description: Irene Hierrezuelo outside her home in Havana. She is counting the days to be reunited with her daughter, Sulay Falconet, who moved to Houston in 2012.
item.media:credit: Lisette Poole for The New York Times
item.description: With visa processing suspended at the Havana embassy, Cubans who have waited years to reunite with family members now have to wait even longer.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Canadian Holocaust Memorial Neglects to Mention Jews
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, center, touring the newly inaugurated National Holocaust Monument in Ottawa last week.
item.description: The plaque at Canada’s first national Holocaust monument, unveiled by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, is being replaced after an international outcry.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: In Mexico City, Pressure to Prepare for the Next Big Earthquake
item.media:description: An aerial view of a collapsed building in the fashionable Condesa neighborhood of Mexico City after last month’s earthquake. Most of the structures that failed predated the devastating 1985 quake.
item.description: Most of the buildings that collapsed in the Sept. 19 earthquake were older. Experts say that’s a warning to reinforce those that remain standing.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.category: Rebsamen, Enrique C, School (Mexico City, Mexico)

item.title: Brazil’s Olympic Committee Head Is Detained in Bribe Inquiry
item.media:description: Carlos Arthur Nuzman, center, the head of Brazil’s Olympic Committee, at the federal police headquarters in Rio de Janeiro on Thursday.
item.description: Carlos Arthur Nuzman had undeclared assets, including 16 bars of gold stashed in Switzerland, prosecutors say. His “right-hand man” was also detained.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO and TARIQ PANJA

item.title: What Is the Iran Nuclear Deal? And Why Does Trump Hate It?
item.media:description: Inspectors with the International Atomic Energy Agency in 2014 at a nuclear site south of Tehran.
item.media:credit: Kazem Ghane/Islamic Republic News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: President Trump has suggested he will “decertify” Iran’s compliance with the 2015 nuclear agreement. But that does not necessarily kill the deal.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Obama, in Brazil, Offers Familiar Slogan to Corporate Audience
item.media:description: About 1,000 people in São Paulo paid $1,500 to $2,400 to hear former President Barack Obama speak on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Felipe Rau/Estado Conteudo, via Associated Press Images
item.description: In a paid address titled “Change the World? Yes, You Can,” the former president steered clear of political controversies at home and in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON and ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Las Vegas, Harvey Weinstein, Spain: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and LANCE BOOTH

item.title: Trump Approves Iran Strategy; No Word Yet on Nuclear Deal
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday at the White House.
item.description: President Trump has been expected to withdraw certification of the nuclear deal since he declared at the United Nations General Assembly that the agreement was “embarrassing to the United States.”
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Las Vegas, Gun Control, North Korea: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Deadly Ambush of Green Berets in Niger Belies a ‘Low-Risk’ Mission
item.description: The deaths of three Special Forces troops raised questions about how they assess threats, as well as about their oversight, Pentagon officials said.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb

item.title: New Species of Sponges Found on the Pacific Seafloor
item.media:description: Plenaster craigi are tiny, newly discovered sponges that live on rock nodules targeted for deep-sea mining on the Pacific Ocean seafloor.
item.description: The tiny creatures live on rock nodules containing metals like iron, cobalt and copper that are targeted for deep-sea mining in the Clarion-Clipperton Zone.
item.dc:creator: XIAOZHI LIM

item.title: Vatican Shines Light on Child Abuse as Claims Against Priests Persist
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Wednesday. He has said that the church “arrived late” to the sexual abuse crisis.
item.description: The church is holding a congress in Rome on protecting children from online abuse, but with a new scandal involving a priest, the timing is awkward.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Edward Heath Would Have Faced Sex Abuse Inquiry, Say U.K. Police
item.media:description: Edward Heath in London in 1971, when he was prime minister of Britain.
item.description: The police said their investigation did not draw any conclusions about “the likely guilt or innocence” of the former prime minister, who died in 2005.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Catalonia Separatism Revives a Long-Dormant Spanish Nationalism
item.media:description: Demonstrators rallied in Madrid last week in favor of Spanish unity and against Catalonia’s push for separation.
item.description: While stirring separatist instincts in Catalonia, the independence referendum has also deepened pride elsewhere in a unified Spanish identity.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Europe Is Called ‘Willfully Blind’ to Risks Afghan Deportees Face
item.media:description: Afghans who were deported from Germany to Afghanistan at Kabul International Airport in December. The United Nations says Europe is ignoring the dangers of their return to the strife-torn country.
item.description: Amnesty International said European countries had returned about 10,000 Afghan asylum seekers to escalating violence and an acute humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Europe Edition: Catalonia, Las Vegas, Google: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Letter 28: Australia’s Battle Between Rigidity and Flexibility
item.media:description: A kangaroo and her joey. To feed or not to feed?
item.media:credit: Aaron Dowling for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s newsletter explores Australia’s sense of when to strictly abide by the rules, and when to ignore, bend or change them.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Canadian Lawmakers Say Pro-Russia Group Tried to Derail Sanctions Law
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland of Canada at Parliament in Ottawa in September. She has been the target of attacks by a pro-Russian group.
item.description: Despite the pressure, Parliament passed a bill to bar Canadians from business dealings with foreigners who have committed human rights violations.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN and JO BECKER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: U.N. Draft Blacklist of Child Killers Includes Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: The aftermath of an October 2016 bombing in Sana, Yemen, by the Saudi-led coalition.
item.description: The Saudis, who were cited for bombings in Yemen that killed children, had insisted they should not be on the annual list.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: 3 Special Forces Troops Killed and 2 Are Wounded in an Ambush in Niger
item.description: Army Green Berets were on a routine patrol as part of a training exercise with troops from Niger, American military officials said.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb

item.title: Las Vegas, Puerto Rico, Rex Tillerson: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Suspect in Canada Terror Attack Had Been Ordered to Leave U.S.
item.media:description: Abdulahi Sharif
item.description: A judge in California in 2011 ordered the man, Abdulahi Sharif, returned to Somalia. Mr. Sharif then went to Canada and received refugee status there.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Turkey Sentences 40 to Life in Coup Attempt Against Erdogan
item.media:description: An unidentified soldier, accused of attempting to assassinate President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in a 2016 failed coup attempt, was escorted from court on Wednesday in Mugla, Turkey.
item.description: High-level military officers were among those convicted of trying to assassinate President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the resort town of Marmaris.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Las Vegas, Tillerson, Puerto Rico: Your Thursday Briefing
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Aide to Iran’s Nuclear Team Is Imprisoned on Spying Conviction
item.media:description: The American and Iran delegations during talks for the nuclear deal in 2015.
item.description: The aide, a Canadian-Iranian accountant, was first arrested last year. Iran’s state-run Tasnim News Agency said he had received a five-year sentence.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Catalonia’s Leader Seeks Talks in Standoff With Spain
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, the separatist leader of Catalonia, said Wednesday that he wanted negotiations with the central government in Madrid to resolve the crisis set off by the region’s referendum on independence.
item.description: Carles Puigdemont said that he wanted a negotiated settlement to Catalonia’s dispute with the central government after the region’s independence referendum.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: A New Zealand Lawmaker’s Spy-Linked Past Raises Alarms on China’s Reach
item.media:description: Jian Yang, a New Zealand lawmaker born in China, at a news conference in Auckland, New Zealand, last month. A recent investigation revealed that he had taught spies in China in the 1980s and ’90s.
item.media:credit: Dean Purcell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.description: The disclosures about the lawmaker raised questions about Beijing’s influence in New Zealand and whether political parties properly vet their candidates.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM

item.title: Circa Now: New Neighbors, New Considerations
item.description: As charitable organizations help to resettle refugees into American life, a little extra sensitivity during social occasions will go a long way.
item.dc:creator: HENRY ALFORD

item.title: Female-Only Cambridge College to Allow Transgender Women
item.media:description: The policy change at Murray Edwards College does not affect admissions at the the other two female-only Cambridge colleges.
item.description: Murray Edwards College, a part of Cambridge University in Britain, said the social and legal understanding of what it means to be a woman had changed.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Where Video Game Conventions Draw 300,000: Not in the U.S.
item.media:description: The crowd last year at the Brasil Game Show in São Paulo, one of several international video game trade shows that have swelled in size.
item.description: The rapidly growing Brasil Game Show, scheduled for next month, illustrates how important the industry’s overseas markets have become.
item.dc:creator: LAURA PARKER

item.title: Putin Says Russia Has ‘Many Friends’ in U.S. Who Can Mend Relations
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow on Wednesday.
item.description: The Russian leader said his country was “patiently waiting” for political strife in the United States to end so that ties between the countries can be strengthened.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: A Dubai in Libya? Boris Johnson Says It Just Needs to Clear ‘Dead Bodies’
item.media:description: Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson’s remarks about Surt, in Libya, have brought criticism from other members of his own Conservative Party, as well as from political opponents.
item.description: The British foreign secretary said a group of business people could turn a war-torn city into “the next Dubai” if they could just dispose of corpses there.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Tillerson’s News Conference Only Highlights Strains With Trump
item.description: The secretary of state had hoped to douse questions about how long he will stay, but instead further fueled a debate about his future.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, MAGGIE HABERMAN and GLENN THRUSH

item.title: Jakarta Journal: In Indonesia, a Mosque and a Church Foster Friendship Amid Religious Tensions
item.media:description: St. Paul’s Church in Jakarta, Indonesia. About 90 percent of Indonesia’s 260 million people are identified as Muslim, but the country has a small, influential Christian population.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Christians and Muslims share a street and much more in Jakarta, setting an example of pluralism as fears of religious intolerance rise in the Muslim-majority nation.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Kim Wall Was Stabbed After Boarding Submarine, Danish Prosecutor Says
item.media:description: The Danish inventor Peter Madsen in May. His explanations about the death of Kim Wall have been met with skepticism.
item.description: A court also heard that videos of women being tortured were found on a hard drive belonging to Peter Madsen, who has been charged in the journalist’s death.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN SELSOE SORENSEN

item.title: Theresa May, Coughing and Caught by a Prankster, Endures a Speech to Forget
item.media:description: The mock dismissal form included the name of the foreign secretary, Boris Johnson.
item.description: The British prime minister, who needed a commanding speech to quell a warring party, lost her voice and was handed a mock job dismissal note.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: E.U., Citing Amazon and Apple, Tells Nations to Collect Tax
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s competition commissioner, in Brussels last month. She has made taxes a priority of her term.
item.description: The European Commission said it would take Ireland to court for not clawing back billions from Apple, and ordered Luxembourg to recover around $293 million from Amazon.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Australia Wants All Citizens’ Driver’s License Photos, Citing Terror Fight
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull at Parliament House in Canberra in February. He is expected to press for all Australians’ driver’s license photos to be sent to a counterterrorism database.
item.media:credit: Sahlan Hayes/Australian Prime Minister's Office, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is set to push for a major expansion of a facial recognition database. Privacy advocates are wary.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI and ISABELLA KWAI

item.title: Ryanair Plane Is Escorted by Military Jet to Stansted Airport in U.K.
item.media:description: A Ryanair flight at Stansted Airport near London last month. Flights from the airport were briefly halted on Wednesday because of security concerns.
item.description: The Royal Air Force tracked the flight, which originated in Kaunas, Lithuania, because of a security threat that the airline later said was most likely a hoax.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Europe Edition: Spain, Las Vegas, Theresa May: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Mattis Contradicts Trump on Iran Deal Ahead of Crucial Deadline
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, right, and Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday.
item.description: Pressed by lawmakers, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis reiterated his view that the Iran accord is working, a quiet break with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: French Parliament Advances a Sweeping Counterterrorism Bill
item.media:description: Soldiers near the Eiffel Tower in April. France’s lower house of Parliament approved a bill on Tuesday to make some emergency security measures permanent.
item.description: The bill would make permanent emergency measures put in place after terrorist attacks in 2015, effectively institutionalizing a trade-off between security and civil liberty.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ELIAN PELTIER
